An intern encrypted the flag using RSA, but mistakenly used a modulus that's the product of two Blum integers. Can you break their scheme? Ciphertext: 5379121132209489998175600878935503183505467785596457653994596442550263308275548645970212100154890762860148827540733023795794234460425773730962563996693647

The flag format is flag{...}
n=8046714556839267865244816229981147832845945163887166248235827526650793603489875760075072534678528637492342713522385648865550986081271415580563751054001157, e=2116523980211597106199306604493313742126380763737630561779602299527366388182857138728125834187308311545028394386886707972867229940767275340541632983634913
The lower 104 bits of p are: 30667949863045146091130636537304557839


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{evjpsay0}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 5379121132209489998175600878935503183505467785596457653994596442550263308275548645970212100154890762860148827540733023795794234460425773730962563996693647
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=8046714556839267865244816229981147832845945163887166248235827526650793603489875760075072534678528637492342713522385648865550986081271415580563751054001157, e=2116523980211597106199306604493313742126380763737630561779602299527366388182857138728125834187308311545028394386886707972867229940767275340541632983634913
The lower 104 bits of p are: 30667949863045146091130636537304557839

extra_info: p=101225868384901529726559518208483099310656901473723935247272136085038178871567, q=79492670057839539177216075891643352731678317153621448593990282043231827769771, Ï†(n)=8046714556839267865244816229981147832845945163887166248235827526650793603489695041536629793609624861898242587070343313646923640697430153162435481047359820
